security_audit.summary: This is a pure prompt-based skill containing only markdown documentation for ASP.NET Core + EF Core + Aspire development conventions. No code execution, no file system access, no network operations, no external command execution. The file contains only text-based guidelines for AI context.

content.value_statement: This skill provides standardized conventions for building ASP.NET Core backend services. It covers architecture patterns, entity design, database operations, manager patterns, DTO mapping, and controller best practices for consistent, maintainable codebases.
actual_capabilities: Apply architecture patterns (Definition, Modules, Services layers)
Create entities with proper inheritance and Guid v7 IDs
Implement manager patterns with CRUD operations
limitations: Focused on SQL Server and PostgreSQL databases
Does not generate code - provides conventions only

use_cases.title: Enforce coding standards
use_cases.description: Apply consistent conventions across a team working on ASP.NET Core projects

use_cases.title: Structure new services
use_cases.description: Set up new services following the Definition, Modules, Services architecture

use_cases.title: Build REST endpoints
use_cases.description: Create controllers and managers with proper separation of concerns

prompt_templates.title: New entity
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a new entity for [entity name] following Perigon conventions. It should inherit EntityBase, use Guid v7 client-generated ID, include proper max lengths for strings, and add appropriate enums with [Description] attributes.

prompt_templates.title: Manager CRUD
prompt_templates.prompt: Implement the Manager class for [entity name] following Perigon conventions. Use ManagerBase, include FindAsync, ExistAsync, ListAsync, PageListAsync, InsertAsync, UpdateAsync, DeleteAsync, BulkInsertAsync operations, and throw BusinessException for errors.

prompt_templates.title: REST controller
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a REST controller for [entity name] following Perigon conventions. Inherit from RestControllerBase, use proper HTTP verb attributes, return ActionResult<T>, use Problem/NotFound for errors, and keep business logic in the manager.

prompt_templates.title: EF configuration
prompt_templates.prompt: Configure EF Core for [entity name] following Perigon conventions. Use proper DbContext, configure relationships with foreign keys, set decimal precision to (10,2) or (18,6), and use AsNoTracking for read operations.

output_examples.input: Create a User entity with email, name, and role enum following Perigon conventions
output: ✓ Entity inherits EntityBase with Id, CreatedAt, UpdatedAt, IsDeleted
✓ Email and Name with max length attributes

best_practices: Use Code First approach with <Nullable>enable for type safety
Prefer Queryable with Select projections over loading full entities
Keep controllers thin - delegate all business logic to managers
Use ExecuteInTransactionAsync for operations requiring atomicity
anti_patterns: Avoid returning ActionResult from managers or touching HttpContext
Do not use string-delimited lists - use arrays or JSON instead
Avoid manager-to-manager references that create tight coupling
Do not wrap responses in ApiResponse at the controller level

faq.question: Which databases are supported?
faq.answer: SQL Server (commercial) and PostgreSQL are the primary databases. Other EF Core providers may work but are not covered.

faq.question: What is the maximum project size?
faq.answer: No hard limits. Conventions scale from small APIs to large enterprise backends with multiple bounded contexts.

faq.question: How does this integrate with existing code?
faq.answer: Designed for Perigon template projects. Existing ASP.NET Core projects can adopt conventions selectively.

faq.question: Is my data safe with this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill only provides text-based conventions. It does not access files, execute code, or transmit data.

faq.question: Why is my code not generating?
faq.answer: This skill provides conventions and guidelines. It does not generate code - it instructs the AI on how to write code.

faq.question: How is this different from other .NET skills?
faq.answer: Perigon focuses on specific architecture (Definition, Modules, Services), EF Core patterns, and Aspire integration with strict conventions.
